Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Analysis and Solution Methods for Function Robust Optimization Models

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to study a new class of optimization models where general shape constraints specify the function form, and a maximin criterion is used to resolve the function ambiguity. For many data driven decision problems the functions specifying the problem are obtained from the data through model fitting. This model fitting is done based on a presumed form of the function. The decisions are subsequently made by optimizing the fitted functions. In the modeling framework the function set is specified using properties of the function and non-parametric model fitting. Such problems are called function robust optimization problems. Different types of function robust models will be analyzed and algorithms will be developed for solving these models.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to the development of a new class of optimization modeling techniques and algorithms for solving such models. The solutions obtained from such models are expected to be more robust and efficient under data uncertainty when compared to those obtained from the classical known approaches. A general methodological framework that allows ambiguity in the function form will present a significant conceptual advancement to the field of optimization based decision making. Applications of such problems range from topics in management, intelligent control, and engineering design. Experiments will be performed to validate the algorithms, and to compare the properties of the solutions generated from the new modeling technique.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The functions modeling a decision model in many decision problems are obtained by solving a model fitting problem that presumes a specific form of the function. In such an approach the solution of the model fitting problem specifies the parameters of the assumed function. In this approach, the decisions are made as a separate problem using the fitted functions. The goal of the proposed research was to study a new class of optimization models where general shape constraints specify the function form, and a maximin criterion is used to resolve the function ambiguity. 

The research developed a general theory for solving such problems. The theory was first developed for a problem where the functional relationship between price and demand of a product is known only through the shape of the function. These problems were efficiently solved, and through extensive testing it was demonstrated that the out-of-sample performance of the functional robust framework is superior to the one which assume the form of the function in arriving at model decisions. 

Algorithms were developed for solving the multi-variate cases, where the functions are ambiguous but piecewise linear convex or convex. In the first case, it was shown that the problem admits several mixed binary formuations. Computational results compared these alternative formulations. A novel algorithm was subsequently developed for the more general convex case, and its convergence properties were established. These algorithms were then considered within the framework of distributionally robust optimization and solved efficiently using a cutting surface algorithm. It was shown that models of moderate size could be solved effectively.

Duality theory was used to develop formulations of problems involving specification of ambiguity in the probability distribution using a Wasserstein ambiguity set. It was shown that a separation problem in case of logistic regression could be solved efficiently. It was also demonstrated that the resulting optimization framework gives improved out-of-sample predictive performance of the outcomes when the number of available samples is small. Thus validating the value of functional and distributional robustness in generating improved decisions.

Several research papers were written and talks were given to disseminate the results. Two of these papers have published in flagship journals. A PhD student working on the proposed topic has graduated.
